description: knur +‎ -le (“diminutive”), from Middle English knarre (“knot in wood”), earlier sense “a stone”, likely influenced by Old Norse knǫrr.
gnarl is a later variant, from gnarled, via knurled.

entries.meaning: A crossgrained protuberance; a nodule; a boss or projection.
A lined or crossgrained pattern of ridges or indentations rolled or pressed into a part for grip.

verbs.description: knurl (third-person singular simple present knurls, present participle knurling, simple past and past participle knurled)

entries.meaning: To roll or press a pattern of ridges or indentations into a part for grip.
